 Your statement that the idea was not developed until the 15th century is absolutely incorrect. It is easy to defend the apologist, as he was giving the view of various Christians on this all the way back early Christianity.
 [*]St. Hilary of Poitiers (ca. 315-367 A.D.): "Many are of the opinion that the genealogy which Matthew lists is to be ascribed to Joseph and the genealogy listed by Luke is to be ascribed to Mary, in that, since the man is called the head of the woman. her generation is also named for the man.."  (in his Novae Patrum Bibliothecae)[*]Irenaeus: "Who was of a virgin who was of the stock of David." (in his "Against Heretics")[*]Justin Martyr: "Therefore (Christ) revealed to us all that we have perceived by his grace out of the Scriptures, so that we know Him to be the first-begotten of God, and to be before all creatures; likewise to be the Son of the patriarchs, since He became flesh from the Virgin descended from them, and submitted to become a man without comeliness, dishonoured, and subject to suffering. ... He said that He was the Son of man, either because He had been born from the Virgin, who was, as I said, descended from the stock of David and Jacob and Isaac and Abraham: or because Abraham was the father both of Himself and of those whom I have enumerated, from whom Mary derives her descent. For we know that the fathers of women are the fathers likewise of those children whom their daughters bear." (in "Dialogue with Trypho")The first statement is direct, and states that by the 4th century at least, "many" were of this view. The 2nd two reveal the view that Christ is descended from Mary, which would have to come from the Luke geneology--there's no where else to infer that, esp. considering that Matthew has Joseph. I am certain there are other early writers that also give this indication--Origen for one, I believe.

 The earliest evidence I've seen of belief in a Mary Davidic lineage is from the 2nd century with Irenaus, and Tertullian also mentions the idea around the end of the 2nd century. But regardless, we need to remember a few important points here: 
 [*]It would take some time for a belief like that to become widespread (assuming it wasn't believed from the get-go already), and so the belief would probably have been around and growing BEFORE the dates it appears in writings. It is very unlikely that the the earliest reference to the belief stands as the very first time the belief existed anywhere by anyone.[*]But even aside from that, the fact that we have a given date (or at least approximate date) of a reference to a belief in no way automatically means the belief didn't exist before then. All it can mean for certain is that it's the first record of the belief that we have.
